Description: Ovoid marl pottery jar with flat base, ledge rim and two cylindrical pierced handles on the shoulder, decorated in brown paint with two boats(one each side), below which is a skin on a pole flanked by two cabins; below the handles on each side is a Naqada plants accompanied by a line of s-motifs. Wavy lines are painted above and over the handles; a single wavy line encircles the top of the rim, a spiral is painted on the base.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir Gaston C C Maspero
Curator's comments: Like Decorated ware D41s in Petrie’s Petrie’s Corpus of Prehistoric Pottery (1921). The decoration is symmetrical on both sides. Both boats have a crossed line emblem on the standard. There are remnants of content in the interior, and remains of cordage in the handles. Published: G. Graff, Les peintures sur vases de Naqada I–Naqada II: Nouvelle approche sémiologique de l’iconographie prédynastique, Leuven (2009), cat. no. 321.
Condition: poor - worn and incomplete, mended from fragments. Accretions on surface
